name: Tbilisi
fun_fact: Fun fact: Cafe Daphna is the only place in Tbilisi where you can mix and match your khinkali fillingsâ€”they offer eight types including 'urban style' with greens, mushroom, and potato varieties, breaking the traditional beef-and-pork rule and making Instagram-worthy dumplings with dusky pink walls.

hero_dishes.name: Khinkali at Pasanauri
hero_dishes.description: Soup dumplings filled with spiced meat and broth, twisted at the top like a pleated sackâ€”juicy, savory, and eaten with your hands
hero_dishes.origin_story: Pasanauri is named after the village considered the birthplace of khinkali. This chain has 6 convenient locations throughout Tbilisi. The technique: pick up by the top knob, bite a hole in the bottom, suck out the broth, then eat the dumpling. The top is discarded
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Pasanauri (6 locations in central Tbilisi), Cafe Daphna (8 varieties including mix-and-match), Shemomechama Old Tbilisi, or Maspindzelo

hero_dishes.name: Khachapuri on a Skewer at Chashnagiri
hero_dishes.description: Melted cheese wrapped in dough on a skewer, grilled over charcoal and smothered in butterâ€”gooey, smoky, heart-stopping
hero_dishes.origin_story: Chashnagiri in downtown Tbilisi invented this genius variation: khachapuri (cheese bread) cooked on a barbecue skewer. The cheese melts into the dough, the butter soaks in, and the result is Instagram gold

hero_dishes.name: Khabidzgina at Kade
hero_dishes.description: Ossetian pie filled with cheese and potatoesâ€”crispy outside, molten inside, unique to the mountain regions
hero_dishes.origin_story: Kade started as a summer cafe in Stepantsminda (Kazbegi mountains) and opened a Tbilisi branch. Their Mtiuleti region specialties include khabidzgina and potato-cheese khinkali, regarded as the best versions in Georgia
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Kade (Tbilisi location or original Stepantsminda cafe)

hero_dishes.name: Traditional Khinkali at Khinkali House
hero_dishes.description: Classic pork-and-beef khinkali served 24/7â€”perfect for late-night cravings
hero_dishes.origin_story: Khinkali House in central Tbilisi is open 24 hours, serving traditional khinkali, barbecue, and salads. It's where locals go after a night out for hot dumplings at 3am

signature_drinks.name: Georgian Wine (Saperavi, Rkatsiteli)
signature_drinks.description: Ancient wine made in qvevri clay vessels buried undergroundâ€”tannic, amber, unlike anything else
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Georgia claims 8,000 years of winemaking. Orange wine (white grapes fermented with skins) is the traditional method. Served in carafes with meals, wine is sacred here. Toast-masters lead elaborate toasts at feasts

signature_drinks.name: Chacha
signature_drinks.description: Grape pomace brandyâ€”strong, clear, and served as a digestif or with toasts
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Georgia's firewater, distilled from grape skins after winemaking. Served in small glasses after meals or during toasts. Locals claim it aids digestion after heavy khinkali meals

food_culture_notes: Never eat the top knob of khinkaliâ€”it's just a handle for picking up the dumpling
Khinkali etiquette: use hands only, bite a hole for broth, then eat. Knives and forks are amateur hour
